content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, my strategy would be to aim for consistency and maximize earnings over the 75 rounds. Given that choosing 'R' yields a higher payoff when the opponent chooses 'B' (35$ vs 0$), and choosing 'B' when the opponent chooses 'R' is still profitable (35$ instead of 45$), I would consider it reasonable to choose 'R' as my default strategy. However, if I were concerned about the opponent adapting their strategy based on my choices, I might switch between 'R' and 'B' every few rounds to make it harder for them to predict my moves. In this case, I would choose: R{}. But remember, this is just one possible approach among many that could be taken in this game. The optimal strategy might depend on factors such as the opponent's likely strategy, the payoff structure of the game, and other unknown variables.
